fields.Title of Presentation: Comprehensive operational malaria control using IRS, MDA, IPTp and MSAT in one high transmission district of NE Uganda
fields.Conference / Meeting Name: American Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene
fields.Description/Abstract:
In 2008, the Ugandan Ministry of Health's National Malaria Control Program and Pilgrim Africa (a Ugandan NGO) implemented a comprehensive malaria control intervention in one
district in NE Uganda with very high malaria endemicity. A pre-intervention
epidemiological survey (1500 individuals) was carried out August 2008 and showed
48% of children 15 and under positive by rapid diagnostic test (RDT), while 15% of
those over 15 were positive. Indoor residual spraying (IRS) with a pyrethroid insecticide,
lambda-cyhalothrin, was conducted in Katakwi District in November of 2008,
concurrently with a medical campaign of mass drug administration (MDA) of
antimalarials with dihydroartemesinin-piperaquine for children aged 4 mo to 15 years,
mass screening and treating (MSAT) with artemisinin-naphthoquine for >15, and
pregnancy testing for all menstruating girls and women, with all pregnancy positives
referred either for intermittent preventive treatment in pregnancy (IPTp) or for treatment
if also positive for malaria.  The population covered by interventions was estimated by
census to be 150,000, but found in practice to be higher. 172,260 people were covered
by IRS and 107,159 people were attended to in the medical campaign. A post-
intervention RDT survey (1600 individuals) was conducted in April 2009, and showed
that 16% of children between 4 mo and 15 years had a positive result and 4%
of persons over 15 were positive. Analysis of national health center data show a
convincing reduction of malaria morbidity associated with the intervention package with
an 80% drop in reported median malaria cases in the district in both patients under 5
and those over 5 for the 6 months following the combined intervention (p <0.001). This
overall 67% reduction in parasitemia after one round of IRS + MDA/MSAT is steeper
than the ~33%-55% reported elsewhere for lambda-cyhalothrin IRS alone in areas with
good susceptibility. Simulation with openmalaria indicates the added benefit contributed
by MDA/MSAT is not merely due to seasonal variation and may have been more than
additive.
